newsitem.title: USA: Intuit sees FY97 revs likely below forecast.
newsitem.headline: Intuit sees FY97 revs likely below forecast.

text.p: Intuit Inc, one of the largest U.S. providers of financial software, on Thursday said its sales growth remained weak, leading it to expect that its fiscal 1997 revenues could fall below previous forecasts.
"We do expect slower overall revenue growth for the remainder of the year," Chief Financial Officer James Heeger said in a teleconference.
He said revenue for the fiscal year ending July 1997 would come in "at or perhaps somewhat below the low end of the $600 to $620 million range we discussed last quarter."

Earlier, Intuit reported an operating profit of $0.16 a share, before charges, on sales of $136.3 million for the fiscal third quarter ended April 30, versus an operating profit of $0.16 a share on $132 million in sales last year.
The earnings per share figure matched analysts' consensus estimate of $0.16 a share, according to First Call.
Intuit also announced a letter of intent to sell its Parsons Technology unit to Broderbund Software Inc.
Heeger said taking Parsons out of Intuit's financial statements would reduce fiscal 1997 sales by about $90 million and earnings per share by about $0.10 on a pro forma basis.
